title: Why Manchester United's meeting with Partizan Belgrade is a reminder of how toughest of times can inspire European glory
text:
Even now, 53 years on from the last time Manchester United and Partizan Belgrade met in Europe, Paddy Crerand can picture Matt Busby, crushed, despairing and emotionally spent.

Another European campaign that promised so much was over at the semi-final stage for the third time running and Busby appeared to have stomached as much as he could take. One by one, United’s players filed out of the Old Trafford dressing room in silence until, by the end, there was just Crerand and his manager left.

The pair had grown close over the years but Crerand had not seen his fellow Scot like this before. “He was going to quit, he was going to give up at the end of the season and, I think, retire from football,” Crerand recalled this week.

“He was so down after that game, you wouldn’t believe it. You have to remember he was the man who took on the Football League secretary Alan Hardaker and instigated English teams in Europe and here he was mumbling about never winning the European Cup. I told him we would. ‘We’ll win it next year boss, we’ll win it next year’.”

It was never mentioned but the memory of Munich and the air crash that had claimed 23 lives eight years earlier had hung over that tie against Partizan and seemed to amplify Busby’s emotional distress. Belgrade, and the Partizan Stadium, had been the scene of United’s dramatic 3-3 draw against Red Star in February 1958, when the Busby Babes booked their place in the European Cup semi-finals only for tragedy to strike after that ill-fated refuelling stop on the way home at Munich-Riem airport.

Returning to Belgrade with a team rebuilt out of the ashes of one of football’s worst disasters was always going to be an acutely sensitive experience for the crash survivors, Busby, Bobby Charlton, Bill Foulkes and Harry Gregg. “There wasn’t any mention of ‘58 on the plane but people were thinking about it. It was there,” Crerand said. “I think only they could tell you what they were feeling.”
